result.value:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/31135034
* Lin, K. T. & Krainer, A. R. PSI-Sigma: a comprehensive splicing-detection method for short-read and long-read RNA-seq analysis. Bioinformatics, doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btz438 (2019).

Percent Spliced-In (PSI) values are commonly used to report alternative pre-mRNA splicing (AS) changes. However, previous PSI-detection methods are limited to specific types of AS events. PSI-Sigma is using a new splicing index (PSIΣ) that is more flexible, can incorporate novel junctions, and can compute PSI values of individual exons in complex splicing events.
* PSI-Sigma is now published: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/31135034

For short-read RNA-seq data, please generate .bam, .bai and .SJ.out files by using STAR (https://github.com/alexdobin/STAR).
```
###This is an example for short-read RNA-seq###
STAR --runThreadN 6 \
	--outSAMtype BAM SortedByCoordinate \
	--outFilterIntronMotifs RemoveNoncanonical \
	--genomeDir ~/index/starR100H38 \
	--twopassMode Basic \
	--readFilesIn R1.fastq R2.fastq \
	--outFileNamePrefix <NAME>.
samtools index <NAME>.Aligned.sortedByCoord.out.bam
```
For long-read RNA-seq data, please use GMAP (http://research-pub.gene.com/gmap/src/gmap-gsnap-2017-11-15.tar.gz) or minimap2 (https://github.com/lh3/minimap2).
BASH2*
Quick Start
======
Create links to the .bam, .bai, and .SJ.out files in the a folder (afolder). If you are using long-read RNA-seq data, .SJ.out files will be generated automatically since GMAP doesn't produce the file.
BASH3*
Download a .gtf file and sort the coordinates. **(NOTE: sorting .gtf file is necessary!)**
BASH4*
Create two files: (1) groupa.txt and (2) groupb.txt. Please put the full name or the suffix of your .bam files in the groupa.txt or groupb.txt. For example, the suffix of a "Sequins_MixA.Aligned.sortedByCoord.out.bam" file is "Sequins_MixA". Groupa.txt will be compared with groupb.txt. Below is an example:
BASH5*
Run dummyai.pl. After the .gtf file, please specify 1 for short-read RNA-seq and 2 for long-read RNA-seq. The last column is used to specify the minimum number of supporting reads for an AS event (10 is specified in the example below).
BASH6*
That's it.
Filtered results (p<0.01) will be listed in the PSIsigma_r10_ir3.sorted.txt.

* Event Region: Genomic coordinates of the splicing event.
 * Gene Symbol: Gene symbol of the splicing event.
 * Target Exon: Genomic coordinates of the alternative exon.
 * Event Type: Category of the splicing event.
 * N: the number of valid samples in groupa.txt (influenced by the number of supporting reads).
 * T: the number of valid samples in groupb.txt (influenced by the number of supporting reads).
 * Exon Type: Whether the exon is a novel exon or an exon related to nonsense mediated decay (NMD).
 * Reference Transcript: The transcript ID in the gene annotation file.
 * ΔPSI (%): the average difference of PSI values in groupa.txt and groupb.txt.
 * T-test p-value: p-value derived from two-sample t-test.
 * FDR (BH): false discovery rate based on the p-values. 
 * N Values: It shows all valid PSI values derived from the .SJ.out.tab files based on groupa.txt. (influenced by the number of supporting reads).
 * T Values: It shows all valid PSI values derived from the .SJ.out.tab files based on groupb.txt. (influenced by the number of supporting reads).
 * Database ID: It shows the accession number of the splicing event in the database of PSI-Sigma (e.g., PSIsigma.db).

* PDL::LiteF
 * PDL::Stats
 * PDL::GSL::CDF
 * Statistics::Multtest
 * Statistics::R (For version 1.9k and when --adjp 2 is used)

result.original_header: Gene Expression Analysis for nanopore long-read RNA-seq
result.value:
To use the PSIsigma-longread-gene-expression.pl:
```
perl ~/PSIsigma/PSIsigma-longread-gene-expression.pl Homo_sapiens.GRCh38.87.sorted.gtf Experiment.Aligned.sortedByCoord.out.bam
```
The default setting is using 4 CPUs to calculate gene expression levels by matching constitutive exons in the gene annotation. An extra perl extension (threads) is needed.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29449409
* K. T. Lin, W. K. Ma, J. Scharner et al., A human-specific switch of alternatively spliced AFMID isoforms contributes to TP53 mutations and tumor recurrence in hepatocellular carcinoma. Genome Res,  (2018).

```
conda create -n PSIsigma r-essentials r-base perl-app-cpanminus
conda activate PSIsigma
conda install python=3.9
conda install -c conda-forge gcc gsl
cpanm PDL::LiteF
cpanm PDL::GSL::CDF
cpanm PDL::Stats
cpanm Statistics::Multtest
cpanm Statistics::R
```

result.original_header: EXAMPLE of INSTALLING Perl EXTENSIONS (without Anaconda)
result.value:
```
# 1-a. If you are a sudo user. Set up working directory for Perl library (Using Perl version 5.18 as an example)
export PERL5LIB=/usr/local/lib/perl/5.18

# 1-b. If you are a local user, you can do like this (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2980297/how-can-i-use-cpan-as-a-non-root-user)
wget -O- http://cpanmin.us | perl - -l ~/perl5 App::cpanminus local::lib
eval `perl -I ~/perl5/lib/perl5 -Mlocal::lib`
echo 'eval `perl -I ~/perl5/lib/perl5 -Mlocal::lib`' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export MANPATH=$HOME/perl5/man:$MANPATH' >> ~/.bashrc

# 2. Install GSL
apt-get install -y git make g++ gcc python wget libgsl0-dev

# 3. Install PDL::GSL
cpan App::cpanminus
cpanm PDL::LiteF
cpanm PDL::GSL::CDF
cpanm PDL::Stats
cpanm Statistics::Multtest
cpanm Statistics::R
```
PSI-Sigma on Windows OS
===========
PSI-Sigma has been tested in Linux and Mac OS environment. You can install Linux bash shell on Windows to run PSI-Sigma.
* Linux Bash Shell on Windows: https://www.howtogeek.com/249966/how-to-install-and-use-the-linux-bash-shell-on-windows-10/

* Filtered Results (p<0.01): PSIsigma_r10_ir3.sorted.txt
 * Unfiltered Results: PSIsigma_r10_ir3.txt
 * Junction Read File: *.SJ.out.tab
 * Intronic Read File: *.IR.out.tab
 * Database File: *.db
 * BAM File: *.bam
 * GTF File: *.gtf (http://useast.ensembl.org/info/data/ftp/index.html/)

PSI-Sigma: A splicing-detection method for short-read and long-read RNA-seq data
© Kuan-Ting Lin, 2018-2024
PSI-Sigma is free for non-commercial purposes by individuals at an academic or non-profit institutions.
For commercial purposes, please contact tech transfer office of CSHL via narayan@cshl.edu

result.description: * Added `$pass = 1 if(!$intronall{$chr}{"$as\t$ae"});` so PSI-Sigma won't entirely skip samples with < 3 exon-skipping reads (too strict for lowly expressed genes). The change is meant to set a minimal exon-skipping reads for `skipratio` parameter.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v2.3

result.description:
* This is an updated to address the issues when `SJ.out.tab` file is not generated by aligners such as minimap2.
* When `--type 2` (long-read RNA-seq) is used, PSI-Sigma will generate `SJ.out.tab` file for each .bam file. `sjFromSAMcollapseUandM_inclOverlaps.awk` is used here but the `and()` line isn't functional. Masked this line to avoid issues in some environments.
* When `--type 1` (short-read RNA-seq) is used, PSI-Sigma will ask if user really want to re-generate `SJ.out.tab` files because this process is very slow. It will be faster if user generates the SJ.out.tab files by using the following two commands:
```
#sort reads by name (computational extensive)
samtools sort -n example1.bam -o example1.SortedbyName.bam
#generate SJ.out.tab file by using the sjFromSAMcollapseUandM_inclOverlaps.awk script in PSI-Sigma's release.
samtools view example1.SortedbyName.bam  | awk -f sjFromSAMcollapseUandM_inclOverlaps.awk > example1.SJ.out.tab
```
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v2.1

result.description:
* Add `--threads` parameters _(optional)_ to speed up steps in generating database (`.db`) and intron-retention (`IR.out.tab`) files. One CPU thread will use 4~8GB RAM based on the number of alignments in a given .bam file (for IR.out.tab files).
* Add `--groupa` and `--groupb` parameters _(optional)_ for users to assign the location of `groupa.txt` and `groupb.txt` files, respectively. `groupa.txt` and `groupb.txt` files are now named with `--name` parameter so that running PSI-Sigma in the same folder won't overwrite each other's `groupa.txt` and `groupb.txt` files for pair-wise comparisons.
* Add `--output` parameters _(optional)_ for users to assign output folder. PSI-Sigma will first generate output files at the working directory and publish output files to the `--output` folder after the run is finished.
* Add `--irclean` parameter _(optional)_ for cleaning up false-positive intron-retention events whose splice sites with different coverage (usually at the 5'-/3'-end of a gene/transcript). `--irclean` will serve as a percentage criteria for **abs(splice-site-A - splice-site-B)/((splice-site-A+splice-site-B)/2)**. splice-site-A and splice-site-B are the read counts of the 5' and 3' splice site of the intron of an intron-retention event, respectively.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v2.0

result.description:
* Added sort function to `PSIsigma-db-v.1.0.pl` so that gene symbols in the `.db` file are always reported in the same order.
* Added sort function to `PSIsigma-PSI-v.1.1.pl` so that the chose of ambiguous events is always reported the same.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9s

result.description:
* Really fixed the `.sorted.bam` file name issue.
* Removed warning for `single-end short read` when users select `--type 2`.
* Corrected Chromosome name of `testsample.db`.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9r

result.description:
* `PSIsigma-ir-v.1.2.pl`: added a line to handle the prefix of IR.out.tab file when the .bam file has a suffix of `.sorted.bam`.
* `PSIsigma-PSI-v.1.1.pl`: added `sort` to the `%name` hash table so that the queue of ambiguous events is sorted. This is meant to avoid generating random differences in file sizes.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9q

result.description: * Added `--variance` to allow users to select `0` Student's t-test **(default)** or `1` Welch's t-test. If `--variance 0` is selected, PSI-Sigma will do Student's t-test even if the numbers of samples in `groupa.txt` and `groupb.txt` are not equal. This will allow users to select the tests based on their assumptions.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9p

result.description:
* The `--adjp 2` function previously removed events whose PSI values are 0s in `groupa` and 100s in `groupb` when one of the replicates is non-zero or non-100. This version corrected the error in the `PSIsigma-FDR-v.1.0.pl` script by adding $nmin and $tmin variables.
* The `rawpvalue.txt.tar.gz` file (already in previous releases when `--adjp 2` was introduced) contains all the records before p-value adjustment. It is the source to find your events in case that certain events may be wrongly removed as outliers.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9o

result.description:
* Automatically switch to Welch's t-test when sample size isn't equal in groupa.txt and groupb.txt.
* Fix a bug for target exon coordinates of A5SS/A3SS events whose alternative splice site is on the left hand site of the host intron (event region). There was a 1 base off in the exon coordinate.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-1.9n

result.description: * Fix a bug when `--irmode 0` didn't skip novel IR events at last/first exon.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9m

result.description:
* `--adjp 2` now uses `p.adjust()` as the default function for p-value adjustment. The R package `qvalue()` is no longer used.
* Added `--trimp` parameter to skip unreliable p-values for p-value adjustment (`--adjp 2`). This parameter will be active when `--adjp 2` is active. FDR values of unreliable p-values (judged by the `--trimp` parameter) will be labeled `na`. By default, the `--trimp` parameter is set to 5. This will assume that records whose `groupa` and `groupb` PSI values **are** below 5% are "unreliable". This will assume that records whose `groupa` and `groupb` PSI values **are** above (100-5)% are "unreliable" as well. Please note that this `--trimp` parameter won't remove any records in the `sorted.txt` output file. The number of records will be the same as what you will get from `PSI-Sigma-1.9k`. Only the FDR values will be changed to `na`.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9l

result.description:
* Added PSIsigma-FDR-v.1.0.pl for a new `--adjp 2` function (P value adjustment).
* The `--adjp 2` function uses `Statistics::R` to call either the `qvalue()` or `p.adjust()` function in R to perform p-value adjustment. `qvalue()` is default.  It is much faster than the original `--adjp 1` function. However, to use `--adjp 2`, you need to install `R` and `Statistics::R`.
* The `--adjp 2` function will remove outlier events whose PSI value is 0 or 100 in all the samples except one.
* The `--adjp 2` function will generate two density plots for p- and q-value distributions as .tiff files. (https://github.com/wososa/PSI-Sigma/blob/master/pvalue_dist.tiff) (https://github.com/wososa/PSI-Sigma/blob/master/qvalue_dist.tiff)
* To install `R`, you can do `sudo apt install r-base` as a super user. For a local user, you can use Anaconda (https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda/user-guide/tasks/using-r-language/).
* To install `qvalue()`, please follow this post: https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/qvalue.html.
* To install `Statistics::R`, you can do `cpanm Statistics::R`.
* `--adjp 0` and `--adjp 1` don't need `R` and `Statistics::R`.
* `--adjp 0` (no P-value adjustment) is now the default parameter.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9k

result.description:
* Fixed a typo to actually check the event region boundaries of `--irrange 5`
* P-value adjustment is now optional with `--adjp 0` parameter.
* Intron-retention detection is now optional with `--irmode 2` parameter.
* Quantification of intron-retention event can now be enhanced by specifying `--irrange 5` to search for +- 5 bases around the target intron and event region boundaries.
* Output denominator.gct is now optional with `--denominator 0` parameter.
* Check `dummyai.pl --help` for more information
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9j

result.description: * PSI-Sigma will output an additional file [.denominator.gct]. The file shows the denominator value of each event (row) for a given every sample (column).
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9g

result.description:
* N and T values in the output file (e.g., `_r10_ir3.sorted.txt`) are now ordered based on the order of samples IDs in groupa.txt and groupb.txt files. The delta-PSI value of samples with a lower-than-criteria number of supporting reads (e.g., `--nread 10`) will be reported as "na" (i.e., not available). An example output of N values is below:
> 16.66|6.25|na
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9f

result.description: * Removed the constraints where intron-skipping reads were limited to only reads within the event region of an intron-retention event.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9e

result.description:
* Fixed a bug for the --skipratio parameter to actually function.
* Corrected the annotation for A3SS/A5SS events whose event region overlaps each other.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9d

result.description: * Added annotation for novel splicing site events in the output file.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9c

result.description: * Remove duplicated A5SS/A3SS records in the database. Changed target exon coordinates of A5SS/A3SS events to the coordinates between closer and farther splice sites.
result.name: PSI-Sigma v1.9b

result.description:
* Fixed a bug for --skipratio parameter. The --skipratio criteria is now triggered only when none of the RNA-seq samples have the skipping junction reads for an exon-skipping event. It was triggered as long as that there is one RNA-seq sample fitting the criteria.
* Enhanced search for novel splice site events.
* Should remove duplicated records in the .db file.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9a

result.description:
* Added a new mode for identifying "novel" intron-retention events. Please specify `--irmode 1` to activate. Or, please use `--help` to see descriptions.
* Added a function to distinguish whether an alternative splice site event might be an alternative transcription start/stop site event. Such events will be labeled as `TSS/A5SS` or `TSS/A3SS`.
* Improved detection of novel alternative splice site events.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.9

result.description: * Added a subroutine to PSIsigma-ir-v.1.1.pl for calculating median values.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8e

result.description: * Removed "chr" prefix and added ".tmp" suffix when generating temporary .db files in dummyai.pl and PSIsigma-db-v.1.0.pl.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8d

result.description: * Remove editing chromosome names in the dummyai.pl
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8c

result.description: * Removed handling of chromosome names in the PSIsigma-PSI-v.1.1.pl.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8b

result.description: * Fixed a bug during database generation. Removed the step adding "chr" to the chromosome names.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8a

result.description:
* Added a new parameter "skipratio". The parameter will prevent reporting certain exon-skipping events supported by very low percentage of exon-skipping reads.
* Fixed a bug when counting the number of samples. Two samples with exactly the same PSI values will now be recognized as two independent samples!
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.8

result.description: *fixed a bug when merging files in the _wososatmp folder. ".chr" is no long required. Instead, the tmp files are now named with "IRtmp".
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.7a

result.description:
* Fixed a bug when reporting multiple-exon-skipping events in PSIsigma-PSI-v.1.1.pl.
* Updated the chromosome names in PSIsigma-ir-v.1.1.pl to allow more organisms to be analyzed. However, chromosome names with "*" or "." will be skipped.
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.7

result.description: * Fixed .SJ.out.tab file name when the .bam file's suffix is "sorted.bam".
result.name: PSI-Sigma-v1.6b

result.value:
* Perl (https://www.perl.org/get.html)
 * Samtools (http://www.htslib.org)
 * R (https://www.r-project.org) (For version 1.9k and when --adjp 2 is used)

```
conda create -n PSIsigma r-essentials r-base perl-app-cpanminus
conda activate PSIsigma
conda install python=3.9
conda install -c conda-forge gcc gsl
cpanm PDL::LiteF
cpanm PDL::GSL::CDF
cpanm PDL::Stats
cpanm Statistics::Multtest
cpanm Statistics::R
```

result.original_header: EXAMPLE of INSTALLING Perl EXTENSIONS (without Anaconda)
result.value:
```
# 1-a. If you are a sudo user. Set up working directory for Perl library (Using Perl version 5.18 as an example)
export PERL5LIB=/usr/local/lib/perl/5.18

# 1-b. If you are a local user, you can do like this (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2980297/how-can-i-use-cpan-as-a-non-root-user)
wget -O- http://cpanmin.us | perl - -l ~/perl5 App::cpanminus local::lib
eval `perl -I ~/perl5/lib/perl5 -Mlocal::lib`
echo 'eval `perl -I ~/perl5/lib/perl5 -Mlocal::lib`' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export MANPATH=$HOME/perl5/man:$MANPATH' >> ~/.bashrc

# 2. Install GSL
apt-get install -y git make g++ gcc python wget libgsl0-dev

# 3. Install PDL::GSL
cpan App::cpanminus
cpanm PDL::LiteF
cpanm PDL::GSL::CDF
cpanm PDL::Stats
cpanm Statistics::Multtest
cpanm Statistics::R
```
PSI-Sigma on Windows OS
===========
PSI-Sigma has been tested in Linux and Mac OS environment. You can install Linux bash shell on Windows to run PSI-Sigma.
* Linux Bash Shell on Windows: https://www.howtogeek.com/249966/how-to-install-and-use-the-linux-bash-shell-on-windows-10/

* For licensing, please contact CSHL tech transfer office: narayan@cshl.edu
